title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
metaDescription: Add chat, conference, real time collaboration and communication (PBX, VoIP, P2P) capabilities, bots and more to your business applications.

Android > lts > guides > Manage_contacts

LTS release 2.61.0Publi√©e le 202-04-06

Manage contacts

Welcome to the tutorial on managing contacts using Rainbow SDK for Android ! By the end of this guide, you'll be able to integrate contact management features into your Android application with ease. We'll cover accessing the user's roster, creating and managing personal contacts, and listening to changes in this information for updating your application's UI.

Rainbow conceptDescription
IRainbowContactRepresents the public interface for accessing information about Rainbow contacts, including the logged-in user. This interface is utilized and returned by various SDK functions.
RosterIn XMPP, one's contact list is called a roster, which consists of any number of specific roster items, each roster item being identified by a unique JID (usually of the form contact@domain). For more information, refer to RFC 6121.
Personal contactsA personal contact is one that you create and manage, exclusive to your account. You have full control over these contacts, allowing you to customize and utilize them according to your preferences

Preamble

This tutorial assumes that you have completed the Getting Started and Connect to Rainbow tutorials, and that you have an active Rainbow application. Before proceeding with contacts management, ensure the following:

  • Your development environment is configured according to the guidelines in the Getting Started tutorial.
  • You have successfully connected your application to the Rainbow platform as outlined in the Connect to Rainbow tutorial.
  • You have obtained the necessary authentication credentials and API keys.

With these prerequisites in place, let's explore the features of contacts management with Rainbow SDK for Android.

Access the user's roster

The user's roster contains contacts that the user has invited, serving as both a contact list and a means of accessing the presence of contacts.

Key Points to Consider:

  1. Roster Compositions: The roster consists of contacts explicitly invited by the user. These contacts can be individuals or entities with whom the user interacts frequently.
  2. Invitation Mechanism: Users can send invitations by specifying the contact's email address. Upon sending, a visibility request is initiated. If the recipient accepts the request, they are added to the user's roster.

To access the roster, you can use the roster property of the Contacts module. This property returns an ArrayItemList containing objects of type IRainbowContact. You can then utilize this interface to display the required information in your application. Below are code examples demonstrating how to implement roster functionality in both Kotlin and Java.

  • kotlin
  • java 
class RosterFragment : Fragment() {
    private val rosterChangeListener = IItemListChangeListener {
        // Handle changes on the UI thread
        val roster = RainbowSdk().contacts().roster.copyOfDataList
    }

    override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View {
        RainbowSdk().contacts().roster.registerChangeListener(rosterChangeListener)
        return view;
    }

    override fun onDestroyView() {
        RainbowSdk().contacts().roster.unregisterChangeListener(rosterChangeListener)
    }
}

public class RosterFragment extends Fragment {
    private IItemListChangeListener rosterChangeListener = new IItemListChangeListener() {
        @Override
        public void dataChanged() {
            // Handle changes on the UI thread
            List<IRainbowContact> contacts = RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getRoster().getCopyOfDataList();
        }
    };

    @Override
    public View onCreateView(LayoutInflater inflater, ViewGroup container, Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getRoster().registerChangeListener(rosterChangeListener);
        return view;
    }

    @Override
    public void onDestroyView() {
        RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getRoster().unregisterChangeListener(rosterChangeListener);
        super.onDestroyView();
    }
}

In a RecyclerView, for example, you can utilize the IRainbowContact interface to display various contact details such as the avatar, first name, last name and company name. This allows you to create a visually appealing and informative user interface for managing contacts within your application.

<!-- Sample layout XML for displaying contact details in a RecyclerView -->
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:minHeight="70dp"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto">

    <!-- Avatar and presence indicator -->
    <com.ale.rainbowx.rainbowavatar.AvatarCardView
        android:id="@+id/avatar"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:avatarDimension="tiny"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        app:presenceDimension="tiny"
        app:presencePosition="bottom_right"/>

    <!-- Contact details -->
    <TextView
        android:id="@+id/title"
        android:layout_width="0dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toTopOf="@id/subtitle"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toEndOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toStartOf="@id/call_button"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:textAppearance="@style/TextAppearance.Material3.TitleMedium"/>

    <TextView
        android:id="@+id/subtitle"
        android:layout_width="0dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toBottomOf="@id/title"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toEndOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toStartOf="@id/call_button"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:textAppearance="@style/TextAppearance.Material3.LabelMedium"/>

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
  • kotlin
  • java 
// Kotlin code snippet for updating layout with contact details
private fun updateLayout() {
    binding.title.text = contact.getDisplayName(context.getString(R.string.unknown))
    binding.avatar.displayContact(contact)
    binding.avatar.displayPresence(contact)
    binding.subtitle.text = contact.companyName
}

// Java code snippet for updating layout with contact details
private void updateLayout() {
    binding.title.setText(contact.getDisplayName(context.getString(R.string.unknown)));
    binding.avatar.displayContact(contact);
    binding.avatar.displayPresence(contact);
    binding.subtitle.setText(contact.getCompanyName());
}

Note: AvatarCardView is a helper view available in the SDK that facilitates displaying contact avatars and presence indicators.

Manage the roster

Users have the ability to manage their roster by inviting people or deleting previously added contacts.

When inviting someone who is in the same company, that person is auto-accepted and added directly to the roster. However, if the invitee is not in the same company, they will have the option to accept or refuse the invitation to join the roster.

Note: The rest of the Invitations module will be covered in a separate guide.

To add a Person:

  • kotlin
  • java 
// This instance can be retrieved through a search operation, for example
val contact = contactInstance

RainbowSdk().invitations().addRainbowContactToNetwork(contact, object : RainbowListener<Invitation, Unit> {
    override fun onSuccess(data: Invitation) {
        // Handle success by updating the UI as needed
        // The Invitation object provides information about the invitation's status
    }

    override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) {
        // Handle errors gracefully, such as displaying an error message or taking corrective actions.
    }
})

// This instance can be retrieved through a search operation, for example
IRainbowContact contact = contactInstance;

RainbowSdk.instance().invitations().addRainbowContactToNetwork(contact, new RainbowListener<Invitation, Unit>() {
    @Override
    public void onSuccess(Invitation data) {
        // Handle success by updating the UI as needed
        // The Invitation object provides information about the invitation's status
    }

    @Override
    public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) {
        // Handle errors gracefully, such as displaying an error message or taking corrective actions.
    }
});

To remove a Person:

  • kotlin
  • java 
// This instance can be retrieved from your roster, for example
IRainbowContact contact = contactInstance;

RainbowSdk().invitations().removeRainbowContactFromNetwork(contact, object : RainbowListener<Unit, Unit> {
    override fun onSuccess(data: Unit) {
        // Handle success by updating the UI as needed
    }

    override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) {
        // Handle errors gracefully, such as displaying an error message or taking corrective actions.
    }
})

// This instance can be retrieved from your roster, for example
IRainbowContact contact = contactInstance;

RainbowSdk.instance().invitations().removeRainbowContactFromNetwork(contact, new RainbowListener<Unit, Unit>() {
    @Override
    public void onSuccess(Unit data) {
        // Handle success by updating the UI as needed
    }

    @Override
    public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) {
        // Handle errors gracefully, such as displaying an error message or taking corrective actions.
    }
});

To Check if a Contact is Part of the Roster:

  • kotlin
  • java 
// Retrieve an instance of IRainbowContact, for example
val contact = getContact()

// Check if the contact is part of the roster
if (contact.isRoster) {
    // Perform actions if the contact is in the roster
    // For example: Update UI or execute specific logic
}

// Retrieve an instance of IRainbowContact, for example
IRainbowContact contact = getContact();

// Check if the contact is part of the roster
if (contact.isRoster()) {
    // Perform actions if the contact is in the roster
    // For example: Update UI or execute specific logic
}

Retrieve a contact

The contacts module exposes several methods for retrieving an instance of IRainbowContact. One common method is to find a contact by its ID. This is particularly useful for scenarios such as displaying a contact's details when a RecyclerView item is clicked, opening a screen containing the contact's information.

If the user's information is not present in the cache, the getContactById() method will return null. In such cases, it's advisable to retrieve the information directly from the server. However, it's important to note that depending on the visibility settings of the searched user, the retrieved information may vary for privacy reasons.

  • kotlin
  • java 
class ContactDetailsFragment : Fragment() {

    private var contact: IRainbowContact? = null

    override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View {
        arguments?.let {
            val contactID = it.getString("ContactID") ?: error("Contact ID is mandatory")
            contact = RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getContactFromId(contactID)

            if (contact == null) {
                fetchContactInformation(contactID)
            } else {
                updateLayout()
            }

        } ?: error("This fragment cannot be shown without bundle")

        // Inflate the layout for this fragment
        return inflater.inflate(R.layout.fragment_contact_details, container, false)
    }


    private fun fetchContactInformation(contactID: String) {
        RainbowSdk().contacts().fetchContactDataById(contactID, object : RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, UserRepository.FetchUserDataError> {
            override fun onSuccess(data: IRainbowContact) {
                contact = data
                updateLayout()
            }

            override fun onError(error: RainbowError<UserRepository.FetchUserDataError>) {
                // Handle error cases
                if (error.errorType == FetchUserDataError.CONTACT_TERMINATED) {
                    // Contact has deleted their account
                }
            }
        })
    }

    private fun updateLayout() {
        // Update views
    }
}

public class ContactDetailsFragment extends Fragment {

    private IRainbowContact contact;

    @Override
    public View onCreateView(LayoutInflater inflater, ViewGroup container, Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        Bundle arguments = getArguments();
        if (arguments != null) {
            String contactID = arguments.getString("ContactID");
            if (contactID != null) {
                contact = RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getContactFromId(contactID);
            } else {
                throw new IllegalArgumentException("Contact ID is mandatory");
            }

            if (contact == null) {
                fetchContactInformation(contactID);
            } else {
                updateLayout();
            }
        } else {
            throw new IllegalArgumentException("This fragment cannot be shown without a bundle");
        }

        // Inflate the layout for this fragment
        return inflater.inflate(R.layout.fragment_contact_details, container, false);
    }

    private void fetchContactInformation(String contactID) {
        RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().fetchContactDataById(contactID, new RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, UserRepository.FetchUserDataError>() {
            @Override
            public void onSuccess(IRainbowContact data) {
                contact = data;
                updateLayout();
            }

            @Override
            public void onError(RainbowError<UserRepository.FetchUserDataError> error) {
                // Handle error cases
                if (error.getErrorType() == FetchUserDataError.CONTACT_TERMINATED) {
                    // Contact has deleted their account
                }
            }
        });
    }

    private void updateLayout() {
        // Update views
    }
}

You can also search for a single contact by their JID rather than their ID. Use the fetchContactDataByJid method, passing the JID as a parameter. This method retrieves the contact associated with the specified JID.

  • kotlin
  • java 
RainbowSdk().contacts().fetchContactDataByJid(jid = "example@domain", object : RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit> {
    override fun onSuccess(data: IRainbowContact) {
        // Handle success on the UI thread if you are updating views
    }

    override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) {
        // Handle error 
    }
})

RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().fetchContactDataByJid("example@domain", new RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit>() {
    @Override
    public void onSuccess(IRainbowContact data) {
        // Handle success on the UI thread if you are updating views
    }

    @Override
    public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) {
        // Handle error 
    }
});

Listen to contact changes

You can listen to changes on an object of type IRainbowContact, allowing your application to be notified when the contact in question undergoes updates or changes its presence state.

When registering a listener at some point in your application's lifecycle, it's crucial to remove it before reaching the end of the lifecycle to prevent potential memory leaks.

  • kotlin
  • java 
class ContactDetailsFragment : Fragment() {

    private var contact: IRainbowContact? = null
    private val contactListener = object : IRainbowContact.IContactListener {
        override fun contactUpdated(updatedContact: IRainbowContact) {
            // Handle update of the contact
        }

        override fun onPresenceChanged(contact: IRainbowContact, presence: RainbowPresence?) {
            // Handle presence change of the contact
        }

        override fun onCompanyChanged(companyId: String?) {
            // Optional callback to be notified when the company associated with the contact changes.
            // This can be useful for updating UI elements or performing additional actions when the contact's company information is updated.
        }
    }

    override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View {
        // Inflate the layout for this fragment
        return inflater.inflate(R.layout.fragment_contact_details, container, false)
    }


    override fun onResume() {
        super.onResume()
        contact?.registerChangeListener(contactListener)
    }

    override fun onPause() {
        super.onPause()
        contact?.unregisterChangeListener(contactListener)
    }
}

public class ContactDetailsFragment extends Fragment {

    private IRainbowContact contact;
    private IRainbowContact.IContactListener contactListener = new IRainbowContact.IContactListener() {
        @Override
        public void contactUpdated(IRainbowContact updatedContact) {
            // Handle update of the contact
        }

        @Override
        public void onPresenceChanged(IRainbowContact contact, RainbowPresence presence) {
            // Handle presence change of the contact
        }

        @Override
        public void onCompanyChanged(@Nullable String companyId) {
            // Optional callback to be notified when the company associated with the contact changes.
            // This can be useful for updating UI elements or performing additional actions when the contact's company information is updated.
        }
    };

    @Override
    public View onCreateView(LayoutInflater inflater, ViewGroup container, Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        // Inflate the layout for this fragment
        return inflater.inflate(R.layout.fragment_contact_details, container, false);
    }

    @Override
    public void onResume() {
        super.onResume();
        if (contact != null) {
            contact.registerChangeListener(contactListener);
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void onPause() {
        super.onPause();
        if (contact != null) {
            contact.unregisterChangeListener(contactListener);
        }
    }
}

Access the user's personal contacts

With the Rainbow SDK for Android, developers can easily manage their own personal contact list, which serves as a personal address book or for other purposes.

The Contacts module offers various methods for manipulating this list, including adding new contacts, deleting existing ones, retrieving contacts from the server, and updating contact information.

Developers can access their personal contacts through the personalContacts property, which provides an ArrayItemList containing objects of type IRainbowContact.

  • kotlin
  • java 
// Fragment for managing personal contacts
class PersonalContactsFragment : Fragment() {
    // Listener for handling changes to personal contacts
    private val personalContactsChangeListener = IItemListChangeListener {
        // Handle changes on the UI thread
        val personalContacts = RainbowSdk().contacts().personalContacts.copyOfDataList
        // Perform actions based on changes to personal contacts
    }

    override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View {
        // Register listener for personal contacts changes
        RainbowSdk().contacts().personalContacts.registerChangeListener(personalContactsChangeListener)
        return view;
    }

    override fun onDestroyView() {
        // Unregister listener when fragment is destroyed
        RainbowSdk().contacts().personalContacts.unregisterChangeListener(personalContactsChangeListener)
        super.onDestroyView()
    }
}

// Fragment for managing personal contacts
public class PersonalContactsFragment extends Fragment {
    // Listener for handling changes to personal contacts
    private IItemListChangeListener personalContactsChangeListener = new IItemListChangeListener() {
        @Override
        public void dataChanged() {
            // Handle changes on the UI thread
            List<IRainbowContact> personalContacts = RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getPersonalContacts().getCopyOfDataList();
            // Perform actions based on changes to personal contacts
        }
    };

    @Override
    public View onCreateView(LayoutInflater inflater, ViewGroup container, Bundle savedInstanceState) {
        // Register listener for personal contacts changes
        RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getPersonalContacts().registerChangeListener(personalContactsChangeListener);
        return view;
    }

    @Override
    public void onDestroyView() {
        // Unregister listener when fragment is destroyed
        RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getPersonalContacts().unregisterChangeListener(personalContactsChangeListener);
        super.onDestroyView();
    }
}

Create a personal contact

To add a contact to your personal contact list, you can use a DirectoryContactEntry object. This object allows you to specify various details about the contact, such as their name, company, contact information, and additional details.

  • kotlin
  • java 
fun createPersonalContact() {
    // Create a DirectoryContactEntry object to represent the new personal contact
    // Fields are optional but at least of of parameter 'firstName', 'lastName' or 'companyName' is mandatory
    val personalContact = DirectoryContactEntry().apply {
        firstName = "First name"
        lastName = "Last name"
        companyName = "Company name"
        companyId = "Company id"
        jobDepartment = "Job department"
        eMail = "your_contact@domain"
        street = "Contact street"
        postalCode = "Postal code"
        city = "City"
        country = "USA" // Country ISO 3166-1 alpha3 format
        state = "NY" // When country is USA or CAN
        directoryType = DirectoryContactEntry.DirectoryType.PERSONAL
        workPhoneNumbers = listOf("+33390671234") // Allowed format are E164 or national with a country
        mobilePhoneNumbers = listOf("+33390671234")
        otherPhoneNumbers = listOf("+33390671234")
        jobTitle = "Job Title"
        additionalInformation1 = "0..255 value"
        additionalInformation2 = "0..255 value"

        listOf("tag 1", "tag 2", "tag 3").forEach { addTag(it) }
    }

    // Call the Rainbow SDK method to create the personal contact
    RainbowSdk().contacts().createPersonalDirectoryContact(personalContact, object : RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit> {
        override fun onSuccess(data: IRainbowContact) {
            // Handle success case
            // The personalContacts list will be updated with the newly created contact
        }

        override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) {
            // Handle error case
        }
    })
}

// Method for creating a personal contact
public void createPersonalContact() {
    // Create a DirectoryContactEntry object to represent the new personal contact
    DirectoryContactEntry personalContact = new DirectoryContactEntry();
    // Fields are optional but at least of of parameter 'firstName', 'lastName' or 'companyName' is mandatory
    personalContact.setFirstName("First name");
    personalContact.setLastName("Last name");
    personalContact.setCompanyName("Company name");
    personalContact.setCompanyId("Company id");
    personalContact.setJobDepartment("Job department");
    personalContact.setEMail("your_contact@domain");
    personalContact.setStreet("Contact street");
    personalContact.setPostalCode("Postal code");
    personalContact.setCity("City");
    personalContact.setCountry("USA"); // Country ISO 3166-1 alpha3 format
    personalContact.setState("NY"); // When country is USA or CAN
    personalContact.setDirectoryType(DirectoryContactEntry.DirectoryType.PERSONAL);
    personalContact.setWorkPhoneNumbers(Arrays.asList("+33390671234")); // Allowed format are E164 or national with a country
    personalContact.setMobilePhoneNumbers(Arrays.asList("+33390671234"));
    personalContact.setOtherPhoneNumbers(Arrays.asList("+33390671234"));
    personalContact.setJobTitle("Job Title");
    personalContact.setAdditionalInformation1("0..255 value");
    personalContact.setAdditionalInformation2("0..255 value");

    // Add tags to the contact
    personalContact.addTag("tag 1");
    personalContact.addTag("tag 2");
    personalContact.addTag("tag 3");

    // Call the Rainbow SDK method to create the personal contact
    RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().createPersonalDirectoryContact(personalContact, new RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit>() {
        @Override
        public void onSuccess(IRainbowContact data) {
            // Handle success case
            // The personalContacts list will be updated with the newly created contact
        }

        @Override
        public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) {
            // Handle error case
        }
    });
}

Update a personal contact

Modifying a contact is much the same as creating one. You need to update an existing DirectoryContactEntry object with the new contact details and then use the Rainbow SDK method to perform the update operation.

  • kotlin
  • java 
fun updatePersonalContact(existingContact: DirectoryContactEntry) {
    // Update an existing DirectoryContactEntry object to represent the updated personal contact
    existingContact.apply {
        firstName = "New First name"
        lastName = "New Last name"
        // Update other contact details as needed
    }

    // Call the Rainbow SDK method to update the personal contact
    RainbowSdk().contacts().updatePersonalDirectoryContact(existingContact, object : RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit> {
        override fun onSuccess(data: IRainbowContact) {
            // Handle success case
            // The personalContacts list will be updated with the modified contact
        }

        override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) {
            // Handle error case
        }
    })
}

// Method for updating a personal contact
public void updatePersonalContact(DirectoryContactEntry existingContact) {
    // Update an existing DirectoryContactEntry object to represent the updated personal contact
    existingContact.setFirstName("New First name");
    existingContact.setLastName("New Last name");
    // Update other contact details as needed

    // Call the Rainbow SDK method to update the personal contact
    RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().updatePersonalDirectoryContact(existingContact, new RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit>() {
        @Override
        public void onSuccess(IRainbowContact data) {
            // Handle success case
            // The personalContacts list will be updated with the modified contact
        }

        @Override
        public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) {
            // Handle error case
        }
    });
}

Delete a personal contact

To manage your personal contact list effectively, you may need to delete certain contacts. This section explains how to delete a personal contact using the Rainbow SDK for Android.

  • kotlin
  • java 
// Method for deleting a personal contact
fun deletePersonalContact(contact: DirectoryContactEntry) {
    // Call the Rainbow SDK method to delete the personal contact
    RainbowSdk().contacts().deletePersonalDirectoryContact(contact, object : RainbowListener<Unit, Unit> {
        override fun onSuccess(data: Unit) {
            // Handle success case
            // The personalContacts list will be updated with the modified contact list
        }

        override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) {
            // Handle error case
        }
    })
}

// Method for deleting a personal contact
public void deletePersonalContact(DirectoryContactEntry contact) {
    // Call the Rainbow SDK method to delete the personal contact
    RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().deletePersonalDirectoryContact(contact, new RainbowListener<Unit, Unit>() {
        @Override
        public void onSuccess(Unit data) {
            // Handle success case
            // The personalContacts list will be updated with the modified contact list
        }

        @Override
        public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) {
            // Handle error case
        }
    });
}

Conclusion

You've Finished the Contacts Guide!

Great job reaching the end of the contacts guide for the Rainbow SDK on Android. You now have a comprehensive understanding of how to manage contacts in your Android app using the Rainbow SDK.

This guide has prepared you to add powerful contact management features to your app, such as accessing rosters, handling personal contacts, and reacting to contact changes.

Whether you're developing a messaging app, a collaboration platform, or any project that needs effective contact management, the Rainbow SDK provides all the necessary tools to ensure smooth user experiences.

Feel free to continue exploring and creating amazing applications with the Rainbow SDK. If you need any help or have questions, our support team is always ready to assist.

Happy coding!

Last updated April, 2024

text: DocumentationAndroid > lts > guides > Manage_contactsLTS release 2.61.0Publi√©e le 202-04-06Manage contacts Welcome to the tutorial on managing contacts using Rainbow SDK for Android ! By the end of this guide, you'll be able to integrate contact management features into your Android application with ease. We'll cover accessing the user's roster, creating and managing personal contacts, and listening to changes in this information for updating your application's UI. Rainbow conceptDescription IRainbowContactRepresents the public interface for accessing information about Rainbow contacts, including the logged-in user. This interface is utilized and returned by various SDK functions. RosterIn XMPP, one's contact list is called a roster, which consists of any number of specific roster items, each roster item being identified by a unique JID (usually of the form contact@domain). For more information, refer to RFC 6121. Personal contactsA personal contact is one that you create and manage, exclusive to your account. You have full control over these contacts, allowing you to customize and utilize them according to your preferences Preamble This tutorial assumes that you have completed the Getting Started and Connect to Rainbow tutorials, and that you have an active Rainbow application. Before proceeding with contacts management, ensure the following: Your development environment is configured according to the guidelines in the Getting Started tutorial. You have successfully connected your application to the Rainbow platform as outlined in the Connect to Rainbow tutorial. You have obtained the necessary authentication credentials and API keys. With these prerequisites in place, let's explore the features of contacts management with Rainbow SDK for Android. Access the user's roster The user's roster contains contacts that the user has invited, serving as both a contact list and a means of accessing the presence of contacts. Key Points to Consider: Roster Compositions: The roster consists of contacts explicitly invited by the user. These contacts can be individuals or entities with whom the user interacts frequently. Invitation Mechanism: Users can send invitations by specifying the contact's email address. Upon sending, a visibility request is initiated. If the recipient accepts the request, they are added to the user's roster. To access the roster, you can use the roster property of the Contacts module. This property returns an ArrayItemList containing objects of type IRainbowContact. You can then utilize this interface to display the required information in your application. Below are code examples demonstrating how to implement roster functionality in both Kotlin and Java. kotlin java class RosterFragment : Fragment() { private val rosterChangeListener = IItemListChangeListener { // Handle changes on the UI thread val roster = RainbowSdk().contacts().roster.copyOfDataList } override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View { RainbowSdk().contacts().roster.registerChangeListener(rosterChangeListener) return view; } override fun onDestroyView() { RainbowSdk().contacts().roster.unregisterChangeListener(rosterChangeListener) } } public class RosterFragment extends Fragment { private IItemListChangeListener rosterChangeListener = new IItemListChangeListener() { @Override public void dataChanged() { // Handle changes on the UI thread List<IRainbowContact> contacts = RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getRoster().getCopyOfDataList(); } }; @Override public View onCreateView(LayoutInflater inflater, ViewGroup container, Bundle savedInstanceState) { RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getRoster().registerChangeListener(rosterChangeListener); return view; } @Override public void onDestroyView() { RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getRoster().unregisterChangeListener(rosterChangeListener); super.onDestroyView(); } } In a RecyclerView, for example, you can utilize the IRainbowContact interface to display various contact details such as the avatar, first name, last name and company name. This allows you to create a visually appealing and informative user interface for managing contacts within your application. <!-- Sample layout XML for displaying contact details in a RecyclerView --> <androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android" android:layout_width="match_parent" android:layout_height="wrap_content" android:minHeight="70dp" xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"> <!-- Avatar and presence indicator --> <com.ale.rainbowx.rainbowavatar.AvatarCardView android:id="@+id/avatar" android:layout_width="wrap_content" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:avatarDimension="tiny" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent" app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent" app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent" android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin" app:presenceDimension="tiny" app:presencePosition="bottom_right"/> <!-- Contact details --> <TextView android:id="@+id/title" android:layout_width="0dp" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="@id/avatar" app:layout_constraintBottom_toTopOf="@id/subtitle" app:layout_constraintStart_toEndOf="@id/avatar" app:layout_constraintEnd_toStartOf="@id/call_button" android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin" android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin" android:textAppearance="@style/TextAppearance.Material3.TitleMedium"/> <TextView android:id="@+id/subtitle" android:layout_width="0dp" android:layout_height="wrap_content" app:layout_constraintTop_toBottomOf="@id/title" app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="@id/avatar" app:layout_constraintStart_toEndOf="@id/avatar" app:layout_constraintEnd_toStartOf="@id/call_button" android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin" android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin" android:textAppearance="@style/TextAppearance.Material3.LabelMedium"/> </androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout> kotlin java // Kotlin code snippet for updating layout with contact details private fun updateLayout() { binding.title.text = contact.getDisplayName(context.getString(R.string.unknown)) binding.avatar.displayContact(contact) binding.avatar.displayPresence(contact) binding.subtitle.text = contact.companyName } // Java code snippet for updating layout with contact details private void updateLayout() { binding.title.setText(contact.getDisplayName(context.getString(R.string.unknown))); binding.avatar.displayContact(contact); binding.avatar.displayPresence(contact); binding.subtitle.setText(contact.getCompanyName()); } Note: AvatarCardView is a helper view available in the SDK that facilitates displaying contact avatars and presence indicators. Manage the roster Users have the ability to manage their roster by inviting people or deleting previously added contacts. When inviting someone who is in the same company, that person is auto-accepted and added directly to the roster. However, if the invitee is not in the same company, they will have the option to accept or refuse the invitation to join the roster. Note: The rest of the Invitations module will be covered in a separate guide. To add a Person: kotlin java // This instance can be retrieved through a search operation, for example val contact = contactInstance RainbowSdk().invitations().addRainbowContactToNetwork(contact, object : RainbowListener<Invitation, Unit> { override fun onSuccess(data: Invitation) { // Handle success by updating the UI as needed // The Invitation object provides information about the invitation's status } override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) { // Handle errors gracefully, such as displaying an error message or taking corrective actions. } }) // This instance can be retrieved through a search operation, for example IRainbowContact contact = contactInstance; RainbowSdk.instance().invitations().addRainbowContactToNetwork(contact, new RainbowListener<Invitation, Unit>() { @Override public void onSuccess(Invitation data) { // Handle success by updating the UI as needed // The Invitation object provides information about the invitation's status } @Override public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) { // Handle errors gracefully, such as displaying an error message or taking corrective actions. } }); To remove a Person: kotlin java // This instance can be retrieved from your roster, for example IRainbowContact contact = contactInstance; RainbowSdk().invitations().removeRainbowContactFromNetwork(contact, object : RainbowListener<Unit, Unit> { override fun onSuccess(data: Unit) { // Handle success by updating the UI as needed } override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) { // Handle errors gracefully, such as displaying an error message or taking corrective actions. } }) // This instance can be retrieved from your roster, for example IRainbowContact contact = contactInstance; RainbowSdk.instance().invitations().removeRainbowContactFromNetwork(contact, new RainbowListener<Unit, Unit>() { @Override public void onSuccess(Unit data) { // Handle success by updating the UI as needed } @Override public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) { // Handle errors gracefully, such as displaying an error message or taking corrective actions. } }); To Check if a Contact is Part of the Roster: kotlin java // Retrieve an instance of IRainbowContact, for example val contact = getContact() // Check if the contact is part of the roster if (contact.isRoster) { // Perform actions if the contact is in the roster // For example: Update UI or execute specific logic } // Retrieve an instance of IRainbowContact, for example IRainbowContact contact = getContact(); // Check if the contact is part of the roster if (contact.isRoster()) { // Perform actions if the contact is in the roster // For example: Update UI or execute specific logic } Retrieve a contact The contacts module exposes several methods for retrieving an instance of IRainbowContact. One common method is to find a contact by its ID. This is particularly useful for scenarios such as displaying a contact's details when a RecyclerView item is clicked, opening a screen containing the contact's information. If the user's information is not present in the cache, the getContactById() method will return null. In such cases, it's advisable to retrieve the information directly from the server. However, it's important to note that depending on the visibility settings of the searched user, the retrieved information may vary for privacy reasons. kotlin java class ContactDetailsFragment : Fragment() { private var contact: IRainbowContact? = null override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View { arguments?.let { val contactID = it.getString("ContactID") ?: error("Contact ID is mandatory") contact = RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getContactFromId(contactID) if (contact == null) { fetchContactInformation(contactID) } else { updateLayout() } } ?: error("This fragment cannot be shown without bundle") // Inflate the layout for this fragment return inflater.inflate(R.layout.fragment_contact_details, container, false) } private fun fetchContactInformation(contactID: String) { RainbowSdk().contacts().fetchContactDataById(contactID, object : RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, UserRepository.FetchUserDataError> { override fun onSuccess(data: IRainbowContact) { contact = data updateLayout() } override fun onError(error: RainbowError<UserRepository.FetchUserDataError>) { // Handle error cases if (error.errorType == FetchUserDataError.CONTACT_TERMINATED) { // Contact has deleted their account } } }) } private fun updateLayout() { // Update views } } public class ContactDetailsFragment extends Fragment { private IRainbowContact contact; @Override public View onCreateView(LayoutInflater inflater, ViewGroup container, Bundle savedInstanceState) { Bundle arguments = getArguments(); if (arguments != null) { String contactID = arguments.getString("ContactID"); if (contactID != null) { contact = RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getContactFromId(contactID); } else { throw new IllegalArgumentException("Contact ID is mandatory"); } if (contact == null) { fetchContactInformation(contactID); } else { updateLayout(); } } else { throw new IllegalArgumentException("This fragment cannot be shown without a bundle"); } // Inflate the layout for this fragment return inflater.inflate(R.layout.fragment_contact_details, container, false); } private void fetchContactInformation(String contactID) { RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().fetchContactDataById(contactID, new RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, UserRepository.FetchUserDataError>() { @Override public void onSuccess(IRainbowContact data) { contact = data; updateLayout(); } @Override public void onError(RainbowError<UserRepository.FetchUserDataError> error) { // Handle error cases if (error.getErrorType() == FetchUserDataError.CONTACT_TERMINATED) { // Contact has deleted their account } } }); } private void updateLayout() { // Update views } } You can also search for a single contact by their JID rather than their ID. Use the fetchContactDataByJid method, passing the JID as a parameter. This method retrieves the contact associated with the specified JID. kotlin java RainbowSdk().contacts().fetchContactDataByJid(jid = "example@domain", object : RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit> { override fun onSuccess(data: IRainbowContact) { // Handle success on the UI thread if you are updating views } override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) { // Handle error } }) RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().fetchContactDataByJid("example@domain", new RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit>() { @Override public void onSuccess(IRainbowContact data) { // Handle success on the UI thread if you are updating views } @Override public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) { // Handle error } }); Listen to contact changes You can listen to changes on an object of type IRainbowContact, allowing your application to be notified when the contact in question undergoes updates or changes its presence state. When registering a listener at some point in your application's lifecycle, it's crucial to remove it before reaching the end of the lifecycle to prevent potential memory leaks. kotlin java class ContactDetailsFragment : Fragment() { private var contact: IRainbowContact? = null private val contactListener = object : IRainbowContact.IContactListener { override fun contactUpdated(updatedContact: IRainbowContact) { // Handle update of the contact } override fun onPresenceChanged(contact: IRainbowContact, presence: RainbowPresence?) { // Handle presence change of the contact } override fun onCompanyChanged(companyId: String?) { // Optional callback to be notified when the company associated with the contact changes. // This can be useful for updating UI elements or performing additional actions when the contact's company information is updated. } } override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View { // Inflate the layout for this fragment return inflater.inflate(R.layout.fragment_contact_details, container, false) } override fun onResume() { super.onResume() contact?.registerChangeListener(contactListener) } override fun onPause() { super.onPause() contact?.unregisterChangeListener(contactListener) } } public class ContactDetailsFragment extends Fragment { private IRainbowContact contact; private IRainbowContact.IContactListener contactListener = new IRainbowContact.IContactListener() { @Override public void contactUpdated(IRainbowContact updatedContact) { // Handle update of the contact } @Override public void onPresenceChanged(IRainbowContact contact, RainbowPresence presence) { // Handle presence change of the contact } @Override public void onCompanyChanged(@Nullable String companyId) { // Optional callback to be notified when the company associated with the contact changes. // This can be useful for updating UI elements or performing additional actions when the contact's company information is updated. } }; @Override public View onCreateView(LayoutInflater inflater, ViewGroup container, Bundle savedInstanceState) { // Inflate the layout for this fragment return inflater.inflate(R.layout.fragment_contact_details, container, false); } @Override public void onResume() { super.onResume(); if (contact != null) { contact.registerChangeListener(contactListener); } } @Override public void onPause() { super.onPause(); if (contact != null) { contact.unregisterChangeListener(contactListener); } } } Access the user's personal contacts With the Rainbow SDK for Android, developers can easily manage their own personal contact list, which serves as a personal address book or for other purposes. The Contacts module offers various methods for manipulating this list, including adding new contacts, deleting existing ones, retrieving contacts from the server, and updating contact information. Developers can access their personal contacts through the personalContacts property, which provides an ArrayItemList containing objects of type IRainbowContact. kotlin java // Fragment for managing personal contacts class PersonalContactsFragment : Fragment() { // Listener for handling changes to personal contacts private val personalContactsChangeListener = IItemListChangeListener { // Handle changes on the UI thread val personalContacts = RainbowSdk().contacts().personalContacts.copyOfDataList // Perform actions based on changes to personal contacts } override fun onCreateView(inflater: LayoutInflater, container: ViewGroup?, savedInstanceState: Bundle?): View { // Register listener for personal contacts changes RainbowSdk().contacts().personalContacts.registerChangeListener(personalContactsChangeListener) return view; } override fun onDestroyView() { // Unregister listener when fragment is destroyed RainbowSdk().contacts().personalContacts.unregisterChangeListener(personalContactsChangeListener) super.onDestroyView() } } // Fragment for managing personal contacts public class PersonalContactsFragment extends Fragment { // Listener for handling changes to personal contacts private IItemListChangeListener personalContactsChangeListener = new IItemListChangeListener() { @Override public void dataChanged() { // Handle changes on the UI thread List<IRainbowContact> personalContacts = RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getPersonalContacts().getCopyOfDataList(); // Perform actions based on changes to personal contacts } }; @Override public View onCreateView(LayoutInflater inflater, ViewGroup container, Bundle savedInstanceState) { // Register listener for personal contacts changes RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getPersonalContacts().registerChangeListener(personalContactsChangeListener); return view; } @Override public void onDestroyView() { // Unregister listener when fragment is destroyed RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().getPersonalContacts().unregisterChangeListener(personalContactsChangeListener); super.onDestroyView(); } } Create a personal contact To add a contact to your personal contact list, you can use a DirectoryContactEntry object. This object allows you to specify various details about the contact, such as their name, company, contact information, and additional details. kotlin java fun createPersonalContact() { // Create a DirectoryContactEntry object to represent the new personal contact // Fields are optional but at least of of parameter 'firstName', 'lastName' or 'companyName' is mandatory val personalContact = DirectoryContactEntry().apply { firstName = "First name" lastName = "Last name" companyName = "Company name" companyId = "Company id" jobDepartment = "Job department" eMail = "your_contact@domain" street = "Contact street" postalCode = "Postal code" city = "City" country = "USA" // Country ISO 3166-1 alpha3 format state = "NY" // When country is USA or CAN directoryType = DirectoryContactEntry.DirectoryType.PERSONAL workPhoneNumbers = listOf("+33390671234") // Allowed format are E164 or national with a country mobilePhoneNumbers = listOf("+33390671234") otherPhoneNumbers = listOf("+33390671234") jobTitle = "Job Title" additionalInformation1 = "0..255 value" additionalInformation2 = "0..255 value" listOf("tag 1", "tag 2", "tag 3").forEach { addTag(it) } } // Call the Rainbow SDK method to create the personal contact RainbowSdk().contacts().createPersonalDirectoryContact(personalContact, object : RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit> { override fun onSuccess(data: IRainbowContact) { // Handle success case // The personalContacts list will be updated with the newly created contact } override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) { // Handle error case } }) } // Method for creating a personal contact public void createPersonalContact() { // Create a DirectoryContactEntry object to represent the new personal contact DirectoryContactEntry personalContact = new DirectoryContactEntry(); // Fields are optional but at least of of parameter 'firstName', 'lastName' or 'companyName' is mandatory personalContact.setFirstName("First name"); personalContact.setLastName("Last name"); personalContact.setCompanyName("Company name"); personalContact.setCompanyId("Company id"); personalContact.setJobDepartment("Job department"); personalContact.setEMail("your_contact@domain"); personalContact.setStreet("Contact street"); personalContact.setPostalCode("Postal code"); personalContact.setCity("City"); personalContact.setCountry("USA"); // Country ISO 3166-1 alpha3 format personalContact.setState("NY"); // When country is USA or CAN personalContact.setDirectoryType(DirectoryContactEntry.DirectoryType.PERSONAL); personalContact.setWorkPhoneNumbers(Arrays.asList("+33390671234")); // Allowed format are E164 or national with a country personalContact.setMobilePhoneNumbers(Arrays.asList("+33390671234")); personalContact.setOtherPhoneNumbers(Arrays.asList("+33390671234")); personalContact.setJobTitle("Job Title"); personalContact.setAdditionalInformation1("0..255 value"); personalContact.setAdditionalInformation2("0..255 value"); // Add tags to the contact personalContact.addTag("tag 1"); personalContact.addTag("tag 2"); personalContact.addTag("tag 3"); // Call the Rainbow SDK method to create the personal contact RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().createPersonalDirectoryContact(personalContact, new RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit>() { @Override public void onSuccess(IRainbowContact data) { // Handle success case // The personalContacts list will be updated with the newly created contact } @Override public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) { // Handle error case } }); } Update a personal contact Modifying a contact is much the same as creating one. You need to update an existing DirectoryContactEntry object with the new contact details and then use the Rainbow SDK method to perform the update operation. kotlin java fun updatePersonalContact(existingContact: DirectoryContactEntry) { // Update an existing DirectoryContactEntry object to represent the updated personal contact existingContact.apply { firstName = "New First name" lastName = "New Last name" // Update other contact details as needed } // Call the Rainbow SDK method to update the personal contact RainbowSdk().contacts().updatePersonalDirectoryContact(existingContact, object : RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit> { override fun onSuccess(data: IRainbowContact) { // Handle success case // The personalContacts list will be updated with the modified contact } override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) { // Handle error case } }) } // Method for updating a personal contact public void updatePersonalContact(DirectoryContactEntry existingContact) { // Update an existing DirectoryContactEntry object to represent the updated personal contact existingContact.setFirstName("New First name"); existingContact.setLastName("New Last name"); // Update other contact details as needed // Call the Rainbow SDK method to update the personal contact RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().updatePersonalDirectoryContact(existingContact, new RainbowListener<IRainbowContact, Unit>() { @Override public void onSuccess(IRainbowContact data) { // Handle success case // The personalContacts list will be updated with the modified contact } @Override public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) { // Handle error case } }); } Delete a personal contact To manage your personal contact list effectively, you may need to delete certain contacts. This section explains how to delete a personal contact using the Rainbow SDK for Android. kotlin java // Method for deleting a personal contact fun deletePersonalContact(contact: DirectoryContactEntry) { // Call the Rainbow SDK method to delete the personal contact RainbowSdk().contacts().deletePersonalDirectoryContact(contact, object : RainbowListener<Unit, Unit> { override fun onSuccess(data: Unit) { // Handle success case // The personalContacts list will be updated with the modified contact list } override fun onError(error: RainbowError<Unit>) { // Handle error case } }) } // Method for deleting a personal contact public void deletePersonalContact(DirectoryContactEntry contact) { // Call the Rainbow SDK method to delete the personal contact RainbowSdk.instance().contacts().deletePersonalDirectoryContact(contact, new RainbowListener<Unit, Unit>() { @Override public void onSuccess(Unit data) { // Handle success case // The personalContacts list will be updated with the modified contact list } @Override public void onError(RainbowError<Unit> error) { // Handle error case } }); } Conclusion You've Finished the Contacts Guide! Great job reaching the end of the contacts guide for the Rainbow SDK on Android. You now have a comprehensive understanding of how to manage contacts in your Android app using the Rainbow SDK. This guide has prepared you to add powerful contact management features to your app, such as accessing rosters, handling personal contacts, and reacting to contact changes. Whether you're developing a messaging app, a collaboration platform, or any project that needs effective contact management, the Rainbow SDK provides all the necessary tools to ensure smooth user experiences. Feel free to continue exploring and creating amazing applications with the Rainbow SDK. If you need any help or have questions, our support team is always ready to assist. Happy coding! Last updated April, 2024 Sur cette pageCe contenu vous a-t-il √©t√© utile ?OuiNonFeedback¬© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProduitsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsLiens utilesDocumentationStoreSupportTarifsAccueilExploreMentions l√©galesContrat de servicesContrat de d√©veloppeurPolitique de cookiesLogiciels tiersEntreprisePartenairesNous visiterRainbowNous contacterSuivez-nous sur

codeBlocks.code:
<!-- Sample layout XML for displaying contact details in a RecyclerView -->
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:minHeight="70dp"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto">

    <!-- Avatar and presence indicator -->
    <com.ale.rainbowx.rainbowavatar.AvatarCardView
        android:id="@+id/avatar"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:avatarDimension="tiny"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        app:presenceDimension="tiny"
        app:presencePosition="bottom_right"/>

    <!-- Contact details -->
    <TextView
        android:id="@+id/title"
        android:layout_width="0dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toTopOf="@id/subtitle"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toEndOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toStartOf="@id/call_button"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:textAppearance="@style/TextAppearance.Material3.TitleMedium"/>

    <TextView
        android:id="@+id/subtitle"
        android:layout_width="0dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toBottomOf="@id/title"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toEndOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toStartOf="@id/call_button"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:textAppearance="@style/TextAppearance.Material3.LabelMedium"/>

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>

<!-- Sample layout XML for displaying contact details in a RecyclerView -->
<androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:minHeight="70dp"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto">

    <!-- Avatar and presence indicator -->
    <com.ale.rainbowx.rainbowavatar.AvatarCardView
        android:id="@+id/avatar"
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:avatarDimension="tiny"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="parent"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toStartOf="parent"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        app:presenceDimension="tiny"
        app:presencePosition="bottom_right"/>

    <!-- Contact details -->
    <TextView
        android:id="@+id/title"
        android:layout_width="0dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toTopOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toTopOf="@id/subtitle"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toEndOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toStartOf="@id/call_button"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:textAppearance="@style/TextAppearance.Material3.TitleMedium"/>

    <TextView
        android:id="@+id/subtitle"
        android:layout_width="0dp"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        app:layout_constraintTop_toBottomOf="@id/title"
        app:layout_constraintBottom_toBottomOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintStart_toEndOf="@id/avatar"
        app:layout_constraintEnd_toStartOf="@id/call_button"
        android:layout_marginStart="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:layout_marginEnd="@dimen/activity_horizontal_margin"
        android:textAppearance="@style/TextAppearance.Material3.LabelMedium"/>

</androidx.constraintlayout.widget.ConstraintLayout>
